sub_concept: Acute vs chronic respiratory acidosis differentiation
stem: ABG: pH 7.36, PaCO2 60 mm Hg, HCO3- 34 mEq/L. What is the primary disorder?
rationale_correct: Elevated PaCO2 with elevated HCO3- and near-normal pH indicates chronic respiratory acidosis with renal compensation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct chronic compensation pattern. | B: Acute would not have significantly elevated HCO3-. | C: pH not alkalemic. | D: No second primary acidifying process.
keywords_to_notice: near normal pH | high CO2 | high HCO3-

stem: ABG: pH 7.30, PaCO2 32 mm Hg, HCO3- 15 mEq/L. Labs: Na 140, Cl 100. What additional disorder is present?
rationale_correct: Anion gap is 25. Delta gap (25-12=13) added to HCO3- (15+13=28) suggests concurrent metabolic alkalosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct because delta gap suggests second alkalotic process. | B: Gap alone does not explain bicarbonate shift. | C: Not primary driver. | D: Abnormal values present.
common_trap: Stopping at high AG without delta analysis.
exam_logic: Use delta gap when AG elevated.

stem: ABG: pH 7.52, PaCO2 28 mm Hg, HCO3- 23 mEq/L. What is most accurate?
rationale_correct: Low PaCO2 with minimal bicarbonate change indicates acute respiratory alkalosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct acute pattern. | B: Chronic would show lower HCO3-. | C: HCO3- not elevated. | D: pH alkalemic.
keywords_to_notice: high pH | low CO2 | near normal HCO3-

stem: ABG: pH 7.10, PaCO2 60 mm Hg, HCO3- 18 mEq/L. What is most accurate?
rationale_correct: Both elevated PaCO2 and low HCO3- contribute to severe acidemia indicating two primary processes.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct because both variables worsen pH. | B: HCO3- too low for isolated respiratory. | C: CO2 elevated. | D: pH severely abnormal.
keywords_to_notice: very low pH | high CO2 | low HCO3-
common_trap: Assuming compensation when both variables worsen pH.
exam_logic: If both variables move acid direction → mixed.

stem: ABG: pH 7.49, HCO3- 38 mEq/L. Expected PaCO2 is approximately 0.7(HCO3-)+20 ≈ 46. Measured PaCO2 is 60. What does this suggest?
rationale_correct: Measured CO2 exceeds expected value indicating additional respiratory acidosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct because PaCO2 higher than expected compensation. | B: Compensation would approximate expected. | C: CO2 not low. | D: pH abnormal.

sub_concept: High anion gap acidosis cause recognition
stem: ABG: pH 7.27, PaCO2 30 mm Hg, HCO3- 14 mEq/L. Na 138, Cl 100. Most consistent with which process?
rationale_correct: AG = 24 elevated, consistent with high anion gap metabolic acidosis such as lactic acidosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct high AG process. | B: pH acidemic. | C: HCO3- low not high. | D: Values abnormal.

stem: ABG: pH 7.30, PaCO2 55 mm Hg, HCO3- 26 mEq/L. What is most accurate?
rationale_correct: Bicarbonate slightly elevated (~1 mEq per 10 CO2 increase) consistent with acute compensation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct acute rule. | B: Chronic would show larger HCO3- rise. | C: pH not alkalemic. | D: No second disorder evident.

stem: ABG: pH 7.05, PaCO2 40 mm Hg, HCO3- 11 mEq/L. What is immediate physiologic concern?
rationale_correct: Severe acidemia can depress myocardial contractility and cause arrhythmias.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct life-threatening risk. | B: Not relevant. | C: Opposite pH state. | D: pH critically low.

stem: ABG: pH 7.40, PaCO2 30 mm Hg, HCO3- 19 mEq/L. What best describes this?
rationale_correct: Low PaCO2 with proportionally reduced HCO3- and normalized pH indicates full compensation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct because pH normalized. | B: CO2 not elevated. | C: Variables abnormal. | D: Not acidemic.
keywords_to_notice: normal pH | low CO2 | low HCO3-
exam_logic: Normal pH does not mean no disorder.

stem: ABG: pH 7.38, PaCO2 60 mm Hg, PaO2 90 mm Hg on room air. What is the primary abnormality?
rationale_correct: Elevated PaCO2 with normal oxygenation indicates hypoventilation without oxygenation defect.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct separation of CO2 and O2 physiology. | B: PaO2 normal. | C: pH normal. | D: CO2 abnormal.
